title.rendered: Minecraft for kids?  Why schools and parents are encouraging video game play

content.rendered:
My friend JP is thrilled. He’s for this weekend minecon registered. He will be with his 9 year old son.

I love the idea of ​​the father/son con, but I don’t get any Minecraft.

I mean, I know it’s one thing, and I have the app, but I really don’t know much more than that. My son’s friends who have older brothers know about it, and he’s asked me about it a few times. I don’t know when I want my 6 year old to expose the deep dark world of games.

I used to have one PS2. I owned it for just a few weeks before I sold it. I spent a whole weekend playing Metal Gear Solid imprisoned and realized he had an obsession that ended. I already spend too much time online, I don’t need to spend more time playing.

Still loves JP Minecraft for his son. He has set up a private server for his son and friends and he can monitor down everything that’s going on. The hacking culture of the game even inspired his son to pick up programming – at the age of 9.

I think that’s pretty cool, but I don’t know much beyond that yet.

JP explained it to me as “virtual Lego.” And it makes sense. “I watch kids create the same thing they do with Lego bricks,” he tweeted. “That’s it. LEGO is missing out on big time in my opinion. That went with 3rd person shooters, what do Legoish ask about that?”

And that’s when I saw my sons playing yet another Lego Star Wars Shooting Games game on the iPad Tonight I’m frustrated I haven’t figured out a better way for her to utilize her digital time. They love building with the bricks, they can easily add energy to the virtual world.

So I’ve been digging in and it’s more than obvious that Minecraft Not only is picking up a love for programming a good thing, it also has many other educational benefits.

Here’s just some of the things that people are saying about Minecraftgreat, and places you can learn more about it to see if it’s something you want your kids to get.

  • Why Everyone Loves Minecraft 1 of 11

    This is a video game that is different. schools who love it. parents love it. kids love it. Click through to see how and why you should love it too.

  • Video games are good for boys 2 of 11

    Barry MacDonald, author of Mentoring Boys, argues that video games are good for kids. “I’ve noticed that most guys who play appreciate the complex problems they solve to be successful [und] willingly delay gratification for weeks in order to get to the next level,” he writes. They also “welcome the social interactions that gaming offers [und] together with others to achieve success. MacDonald thinks we should start young leaders with computers (and games), not shutting them down.

    Image via iStockPhoto

  • Science says gaming is a good 3 out of 11

    A New York Times piece on Minecraft cites studies from Silicon Valley research projects suggesting hand-eye dexterity, memory, and problem-solving skills are improved. Iowa State University had surgeons play video games prior to surgery and found that those who gamed were more accurate in the operating room. “Minecraft extends kids’ spatial reasoning skills, construction skills and understanding of planning,” said Eric Klopfer, professor and director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Scheller Teacher Education Program. “In many ways it’s like a digital version of the Lego.”

    Image via iStockPhoto

  • Compulsory class in a Swedish high school 4 out of 11

Do you want education that thinks outside the box? A Swedish high school has Minecraft as a compulsory course. “They learn about urban planning, environmental issues, getting things done, and even how to plan for the future” teacher Monica Ekman said The Local. “The boys knew some of it before we even started, but the girls were happy to create and build something – it’s no different than art or woodcraft.”

Image via iStockPhoto

  • Some get it 5 out of 11

    Maureen Devlin is a Massachusetts teacher who struggled to keep her elementary school closed Minecraft . “[L] Ast year I observed the way that neighboring students created Minecraft Virtual Animal Habitats provided visitors with the facts and information the endangered animal related to the creators and visitors were fascinated by the shows,” she writes on her blog. “Just yesterday a boy in the playground told me everything about that he and his friends are collaborative Minecraft Creation–the vocabulary he used made me wish I had a dictionary nearby.” Yet her application for a second year was denied. She argues that teachers are bringing Lego and superheroes and board games into the classroom, and that is not otherwise.

    Image via Minecraft screenshot

  • MinecraftEdu 6 of 11

    It is a MinecraftEdu program to bring together classes and teachers from Finland, Sweden and the USA to exchange ideas and educational plans for using the game in the classroom. Teachers all over the world teach children about languages, history and science as a whole Minecraft.

    Image via Minecraft screenshot

  • With this they can relate to your children 7 by 11

    Barmy rhizome did a great post where he had his son teach him what is this world. He warns parents we need to appreciate the things our children are passionate about. “If I don’t try to understand things you find important, we’ll have less and less to talk about,” he writes. “You spend more time on Minecraft than I’d prefer, but if I’m going to get any hope in hell of affecting that apart from clumsy restrictions enforced under penalty of penalty, I got to know Minecraft as you see it.” And so he and his son went on a video tour of the manufactured world…

    Image via iStockPhoto

  • Gender neutral 8 out of 11

    Minecraft is a truly gender neutral game. It’s about building things. LEGO has recently staggered and dished out more soft-colored pieces and sets, Minecraft Cecily’s daughter is straight up good for boys and girls in as are her friends. “At the pool the other day my daughter overheard someone talking about Minecraft and they became instant best friends,” she wrote.

    Image via iStockPhoto

  • Since the coding is 9 out of 11

    Last month I got that schools need to spend more energy on teaching kids how to code instead of asking for budget increases to buy more marriage years. This video is just such a great reminder of the power of computers and how they will become vital in any future endeavor. Simple things like Minecraft get our kids to think like engineers and understand how to manipulate the digital tools to be successful. Watch Jack, Bill, Mark and others explain.

    Image via YouTube Screencap.

  • Then there’s the bad side of the games… 10 out of 11

    The fact I stayed inside all weekend playing Metal Gear Solid is the warning you need to heed when it comes to gaming. As part of a balanced educational program that includes many different environments and ways of learning, it’s wonderful. The dopamine your brain releases when you play games is addictive – it really is. So limit playtime like limiting screen time so you train your child during a lifetime of living in your basement.

    Image via iStockPhoto

  • How do you learn to play? 11 out of 11

    There are tutorials on the Minecraft website and all about YouTube. another site, twitch tvyou can use the Minecraft play life, people watch so you can see what’s going on. (This is good for any video game if you can get a handle on what kind of action your kids want to get involved in)

The judgment?

I will follow my son on this one. If it’s something he continues to ask and show interest in, I’ll play around with him and see how we both feel. In the meantime, I’ll keep trying and finding out what the heck this game is exactly.

how about you Are your kids into Minecraft? Is it a good thing or a bad thing?
